name: Hartmanis–Stearns conjecture
rephrased: The Hartmanis-Stearns conjecture posits that any number that can be generated by a Turing machine in real-time (outputting one digit at a time within a fixed time bound per digit) must be a rational number.
implication_form: If a real-time computable number exists, then it must be rational.
posed_by: Juris Hartmanis and Richard E. Stearns
explained: The Hartmanis–Stearns conjecture is a foundational open problem in theoretical computer science concerning the relationship between time complexity and the computability of real numbers. It posits that if a real number can be computed by a multitape Turing machine in real-time (i.e., the machine writes the n-th digit using only O(n) time steps in total, with the time per digit bounded by a constant), then that number must be a transcendental number. In other words, no algebraic irrational number (which includes all rational numbers) can be computed in real-time by a Turing machine.
related_conjectures: P versus NP problem (related through the broader field of computational complexity)
Time hierarchy theorems (provide foundational results on time complexity)
Conjectures regarding the computability of specific real numbers (e.g., whether π or e can be computed faster than linear time)
Research on the limits of real-time computation in various models (e.g., cellular automata, streaming algorithms)
